refnamediv.refpurpose: Alias of floatval

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: This function is an alias of floatval.

note.para: This alias is a left-over from a function-renaming. In older versions of PHP you'll need to use this alias of the floatval function, because floatval wasn't yet available in that version.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Determine whether a variable is set

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: This is the opposite of (boolean) var, except that no warning is generated when the variable is not set. See converting to boolean for more information.
refsect1.simpara: Note that this is meaningless when used on anything which isn't a variable; i.e. empty (addslashes ($name)) has no meaning since it would be checking whether something which isn't a variable is a variable with a &false; value.
See also isset and unset.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Get float value of a variable

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.simpara: Returns the float value of var.
See also intval, strval, settype and Type juggling.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Get the type of a variable

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Returns the type of the PHP variable var.

warning.simpara: Never use gettype to test for a certain type, since the returned string may be subject to change in a future version. In addition, it is slow too, as it involves string comparision .

refsect1.para:
Possibles values for the returned string are:
"boolean" (since PHP 4)
"integer"
"double" (for historical reasons "double" is returned in case of a float, and not simply "float")
"string"
"array"
"object"
"resource" (since PHP 4)
"NULL" (since PHP 4)
"user function" (PHP 3 only, deprecated)
"unknown type"
For PHP 4, you should use function_exists and method_exists to replace the prior usage of gettype on a function.
See also settype, is_array, is_bool, is_float, is_integer, is_null, is_numeric, is_object, is_resource, is_scalar, and is_string.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Import GET/POST/Cookie variables into the global scope

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.simpara: Imports GET/POST/Cookie variables into the global scope. It is useful if you disabled register_globals, but would like to see some variables in the global scope.

Using the types parameter, you can specify, which request variables to import. You can use 'G', 'P' and 'C' characters respectively for GET, POST and Cookie. These characters are not case sensitive, so you can also use any combination of 'g', 'p' and 'c'. POST includes the uploaded file informations. Note, that the order of the letters matters, as using "gp", the POST variables will overwrite GET variables with the same name. Any other other letters then GPC are discarded.

note.para: Although the prefix argument is optional, you will get a notice level error, if you specify no prefix, or specify an empty string as a prefix. This is a possible security hazard. Notice level errors are not displayed using the default error reporting level.

refsect1.simpara: See also register_globals and track_vars.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Get integer value of a variable

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.simpara: Returns the integer value of var, using the specified base for the conversion (the default is base 10).
var may be any scalar type. You cannot use intval on arrays or objects.

note.para: The base argument for intval has no effect unless the var argument is a string.

refsect1.simpara: See also floatval, strval, settype and Type juggling.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Finds whether a variable is an array

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Returns &true; if var is an array, &false; otherwise.
See also is_float, is_int, is_integer, is_string, and is_object.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Finds out whether a variable is a boolean

refsect1.title: Description

See also is_array, is_float, is_int, is_integer, is_string, and is_object.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Finds whether a variable is a resource

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: is_resource returns &true; if the variable given by the var parameter is a resource, otherwise it returns &false;.
See the documentation on the resource-type for more information.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Finds whether a variable is a scalar

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: is_scalar returns &true; if the variable given by the var parameter is a scalar, otherwise it returns &false;.

note.para: is_scalar does not consider resource type values to be scalar as resources are abstract datatypes which are currently based on integers. This implementation detail should not be relied upon, as it may change.

refsect1.para: See also is_bool, is_numeric, is_float, is_int, is_real, is_string, is_object, is_array, and is_integer.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Determine whether a variable is set

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.simpara: Returns &true; if var exists; &false; otherwise.
refsect1.para:
If a variable has been unset with unset, it will no longer be isset. isset will return &false; if testing a variable that has been set to &null;. Also note that a &null; byte ("\0") is not equivalent to the PHP &null; constant.
$a = "test"; $b = "anothertest";
echo isset ($a); // TRUE echo isset ($a, $b) //TRUE
unset ($a); echo isset ($a); // FALSE echo isset ($a, $b); //FALSE
$foo = NULL; print isset ($foo); // FALSE
refsect1.simpara: See also empty and unset.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Prints human-readable information about a variable

refentry.refsect1:
Description voidprint_r mixedexpression print_r displays information about a variable in a way that's readable by humans. If given a string, integer or float, the value itself will be printed. If given an array, values will be presented in a format that shows keys and elements. Similar notation is used for objects. Remember that print_r will move the array pointer to the end. Use reset to bring it back to beginning. &tip.ob-capture; 
 'apple', 'b' => 'banana', 'c' => array ('x','y','z'));
    print_r ($a);
?>
Which will output: 
Array
(
    [a] => apple
    [b] => banana
    [c] => Array
        (
            [0] => x
            [1] => y
            [2] => z
        )
)
Prior to PHP 4.0.4, print_r will continue forever if given an array or object that contains a direct or indirect reference to itself. An example is print_r($GLOBALS) because $GLOBALS is itself a global variable that contains a reference to itself. See also ob_start, var_dump, and var_export.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Generates a storable representation of a value

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.simpara: serialize returns a string containing a byte-stream representation of value that can be stored anywhere.
This is useful for storing or passing PHP values around without losing their type and structure.

To make the serialized string into a PHP value again, use unserialize. serialize handles all types, except the resource-type. You can even serialize arrays that contain references to itself. References inside the array/object you are serializeing will also be stored.

note.para: In PHP 3, object properties will be serialized, but methods are lost. PHP 4 removes that limitation and restores both properties and methods. Please see the Serializing Objects section of Classes and Objects for more information.

example.title: serialize example

refsect1.para: See Also: unserialize.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Set the type of a variable

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Set the type of variable var to type.

Possibles values of type are:
"boolean" (or, since PHP 4.2.0, "bool")
"integer" (or, since PHP 4.2.0, "int")
"float" (only possible since PHP 4.2.0, for older versions use the deprecated variant "double")
"string"
"array"
"object"
"null" (since PHP 4.0.8)
Returns &true; if successful; otherwise returns &false;.

example.title: settype example
example.programlisting:
$foo = "5bar"; // string $bar = true; // boolean
settype($foo, "integer"); // $foo is now 5 (integer) settype($bar, "string"); // $bar is now "1" (string)

refsect1.para: See also gettype, type-casting and type-juggling.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Get string value of a variable

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.simpara: Returns the string value of var. See the documentation on string for more information on converting to string.
var may be any scalar type. You cannot use strval on arrays or objects.
See also floatval, intval, settype and Type juggling.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Creates a PHP value from a stored representation

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.simpara: unserialize takes a single serialized variable (see serialize) and converts it back into a PHP value. The converted value is returned, and can be an integer, float, string, array or object.

note.para: It's possible to set a callback-function which will be called, if an undefined class should be instanciated during unserializing. (to prevent getting an incomplete object "__PHP_Incomplete_Class".) Use your &php.ini;, ini_set or &htaccess;-file to define 'unserialize_callback_func'. Everytime an undefined class should be instanciated, it'll be called. To disable this feature just empty this setting.

example.title: unserialize_callback_func example

note.para: In PHP 3, methods are not preserved when unserializing a serialized object. PHP 4 removes that limitation and restores both properties and methods. Please see the Serializing Objects section of Classes and Objects or more information.

example.title: unserialize example

refsect1.para: See Also: serialize.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Unset a given variable

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: unset destroys the specified variables. Note that in PHP 3, unset will always return &true; (actually, the integer value 1). In PHP 4, however, unset is no longer a true function: it is now a statement. As such no value is returned, and attempting to take the value of unset results in a parse error.

example.title: unset example

refsect1.para: The behavior of unset inside of a function can vary depending on what type of variable you are attempting to destroy.
See also isset and empty.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Outputs or returns a string representation of a variable

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.simpara: This function returns structured information about the variable that is passed to this function. It is similar to var_dump with the exception that the returned representation is valid PHP code.
You can also return the variable representation by using &true; as second parameter to this function.
Compare var_export to var_dump.

informalexample.programlisting:
1,
  1 => 2,
  2 => 
  array (
    0 => 'a',
    1 => 'b',
    2 => 'c',
  ),
)
*/

$b = 3.1;
$v = var_export($b, TRUE);
echo $v;

/* output:
3.1
*/
?>
